advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Byte magazine</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Atmos from Oric : the definitive computer''<br> ''Now, go !''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET - INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"I met Apple IIc" <br><br> French advert from MAJUSCULE distributor.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983 </strong></font><br><blockquote>Probably the last advert made by T.I. in the UK</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french brochure presented games from #1 to #43</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPT. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The incredible Secam color micro-computer !"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SORD BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You hesitate between two standards."<br> "Rank Xerox doesn't."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This painting was the first and the best known MITS Altair advert. It was created by Kim Behm who has since become a well-known artist. At the first beginning of the personal computers era, this advert seems to be saying: In a near future, everybody around the world will have access to a personal computer.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMTEXT BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> When you buy, lease or rent word processing equipment from AM Jacquard Systems, you get our total commitment, now and in the future, that assures the successful installation and operation of your AMtext word processing system. <br><br> To support that commitment, we have offices in over 100 cities throughout North America staffed with skilled professionals ready to meet your neads with planning, training. supplies, and service... <br><br> ...The AMtext 100 is a true shared resource, multifunction information system capable of supporting multiple work stations and peripherals simultaneously. <br><br> The Amtext 425 and 425A are powerful stand-alone work stations with a full-page video display <br><br> The AMtext 225 is a low-cost system that turns electric typewriters into flexible text editors. <br><br> The AMtext product line includes a complete selection of peripheral devices, including telecommunications, an optical character reader. magnetic card reader, phototypesetters, daisy wheel printers. high-speed line and matrix printers, as well as mass storage on floppy and hard disk drive units. <br><br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1946...</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an extract of the promotional guide. It says: <br><br> <font color="#666666">1946... Today the TO 7<br> 1946: 30 tons, 160 m²<br> Today: 3.5 Kg, 0.01 m²</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OFFICIAL FLYER (VERSO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mainbyte.com" target="_blank">www.mainbyte.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the (rare!) DMX80 printer, the two floppy drive units and SDX FDD interface.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Hyperion is a true portable weighting in at only 18 pounds. It is light on the eyes with its European amber screen and styling. But heavy on performances with many standard features which are expensive necessities for other personal computers. And all for a price that's less that you'd expect...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At the fingertip of the mouse..." <br><br> "... 16/32 bits technology"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure - Page 2 <b>EXPANSION OPTIONS</b><br><br> <b>HRAM.64</b> - High Speed 64Kb Dynamic RAM memory board with parity (up to a total of six)<br> <b>HSIO.4</b> - Four Serial Port Expansion Board (RS-232C or Current Loop).<br> <b>FPB</b> - Floating Point Arithmetic Board.<br> <b>ADC-2D</b> - Two additionaI 5 1/4 inch Double capacity floppy disk drives incorporated within a cabinet (360 Kb total capacity).<br> <b>ADC-2Q</b> - Two additionaI 5 1/4 inch Quad capacity floppy disk drives incorporated within a cabinet (720 Kb total capacity).<br> <b>HDS-5</b> - 5 1/4 inch Winchester Hard Disk 5 Mb formatted capacity.<br> <b>HDS-18</b> - 14 inch Winchester Hard Disk 18 Mb formatted capacity.<br> <b>Tape Backup</b> - 13.4 Mb Tape Backup system for HDS-18 or HDS-5.<br> <b>CRT</b> - Hazeltine 1420/Soroc 120. (Other software drivers available.)<br> <b>Printer</b> - 35 or 55 cps letter quality printer. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ELECTRON USER MAG #1 (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first issue of the official Electron magazine.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://home.iae.nl/users/bverhoev/" target="_blank">The Electron Lives !</a> for the picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
The HP-9810 was the successor of the HP-9100. Although it kept software compatibility, its internal hardware organisation was completely different. The core memory was replaced with volatile MOS RAM chips and the display used the new technology of 7-segment light emitting diodes (LED) instead of cathode-ray tube.
Arithmetic routines were stored in ROM and user programs in RAM. Several RAM extensions, specialized ROM modules and peripherals (paper tape reader/puncher, line printer, measuring instruments) could be connected to the basic model.
The standard version of this calculator included a magnetic card reader located directly behind the two yellow keys at the top-right in the keyboard. While a thermal printer was available as an option, it could only print numeric characters unless you had the Alphanumeric Printer ROM.
The add-on ROMs for this machine came in the form of a block that plugged into the left side of the keyboard; each had its own specialized keys. You can see the edges of the ROM block in the picture; the 3x5 array of keys at the leftmost area of the keyboard is its top. It was common to have more than one ROM extension available in a single block, since you could only plug in one at a time.
With this first generation of programmable calculators, engineers eventually became independant from main frames and computer centers. They could write programs, save, recall and print them off-line; and even easily carry the computer from a place to another... it was a true revolution at the time.
computer.name: HP-9810
computer.peripherals: RAM and ROM modules, Peripherals I/O connector
computer.text: 3 lines of 15 numeric chars. Each line displays one register
